description: Not to include Business Internship. (See BADM 499) Contract approved by instructor, advisor and undergraduate division head is required.

subject: BADM
name: Planning and Managing a Career in Business
description: Course will focus on defining and enhancing life/career goals using leadership assessment, life planning processes, and emotional intelligence discussions, all linked to transition to work.   CL: 2020.

subject: BADM
name: Business Internship
description: Supervised work experience of at least nine hours per week (for 15 weeks in a semester) or minimum 135 hours total; approved by area program director, to include one class meeting a month and individual consultation. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and undergraduate division head is required.   FS: 04/07/2021.

subject: BADM
name: Special Topics in Business
description: Analysis of current topics, issues, and practices in business. May be repeated as content varies by title for a maximum of 9 credit hours per program of study.    CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Principles I
description: Introductory survey of macromolecules, cell structure and function, genetics, and molecular biology.   FS: 10/07/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Principles I
description: Introductory survey of macromolecules, cell structure and function, genetics, and molecular biology. Three lecture hours per week.     Restricted to students who have credit for BIOL 101L but lack the lecture.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Principles I Laboratory
description: (Recommended concurrent with BIOL 101). Experimental examination of basic principles of cell biology, genetics and metabolism.   Three hours per week.   FS: 10/07/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Principles II
description: Introductory survey of plant and animal development, physiology, ecology, and evolution.   FS: 11/04/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Principles II
description: Introductory survey of plant and animal development, physiology, ecology, and evolution. Three lecture hours per week.  Restricted to students who have credit for BIOL 102L but lack the lecture.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Principles II Laboratory
description: Experimental examination of structure and function of plant and animal systems, biodiversity, ecology.   BIOL 101, BIOL 102, BIOL 101L and BIOL 102L must be completed prior to enrolling in 300-level or above Biology courses.   FS: 11/04/2020.

subject: BIOL
name: General Biology
description: Basic biological concepts and issues for non-biology majors. Credit may not be given for both this course and BIOL 120. Three lecture, two laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: General Biology (Audio-Tutorial)
description: Addendum to BIOL 110.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Biology
description: Fundamental principles of human biology. Credit may not be given for both BIOL 110 and BIOL 120.  Three lecture hours per week. Not for major credit.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Laboratory in Human Biology
description: Exercises dealing with basic concepts of human biology. Not for major credit.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Science
description: An introduction to plant science for the non-major. This course does not carry major credit, and is not designed as a prerequisite for other biology courses. Plant development, physiology, genetics, evolution, and ecology will be considered. Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Science Laboratory
description: Laboratory exercises, demonstrations, and audio-visual supplements to BIOL 200. Not for major credit.  Two hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Infectious Diseases, Human Health, and Ethics
description: An introduction to pathogens including bacteria, viruses, and protozoans. Basic elements of the immune system coupled with discussion of how pathogens cause disease. This information is placed in the context of how scientific research leads to the discovery, treatment, and prevention of the disease. The ethical implications of each pathogen and its treatment strategies are discussed.   FS: 03/02/2022.

subject: BIOL
name: Exploration of Infectious Diseases
description: This class goes beyond the classroom to visit sites affected by infectious diseases, like cholera and bubonic plague, in order to put these diseases into context, gaining a deeper understanding of the implications of infectious disease on human health and ethics. This course will experience infectious diseases through the scope of art, literature, and architecture.   FS: 12/07/2022.

subject: BIOL
name: Genetics and Society
description: (Designed for non-major students.) Genetic principles, emphasizing human heredity. Relevance of recent advances in genetics.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 06/06/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Our Hungry World from Malthus to McDonalds
description: Scientific and social issues concerning the interrelationship of culture and agricultural biotic diversity and technology, climate change, resources management, food security, and human health.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Elementary Life Science
description: This course will ensure that elementary education majors will understand the fundamental concepts of Biology. Cannot be used for biology major credit.   FS: 06/01/2022.

subject: BIOL
name: Anatomy
description: Functional anatomy of the human body and its relation to disease processes. Not for biology major credit.

subject: BIOL
name: Anatomy Laboratory
description: The principles of anatomy as demonstrated by microscopic studies and animal dissection.  Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Applied Human Physiology
description: Fundamentals of functional human biology and knowledge of contemporary medical problems. Not for major credit.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Physiology
description: Functional biology of organ systems in the maintenance of the whole organism; homeostatic relationships. Not available for biology major credit.      Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology I
description: Functional anatomy and physiology of the human body, including the integumentary, skeletal, muscular, and nervous systems. Not available for biology major credit.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 10/1/2014.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology Laboratory
description: The principles of anatomy and physiology as demonstrated by microscopic studies, animal dissection, and physiological experiments.   One three-hour laboratory per week.   FS: 10/1/2014.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology II
description: Functional anatomy and physiology of the human body, including the cardiovascular, endocrine, excretory, reproductive, digestive, and respiratory systems. Not available for biology major credit.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology Laboratory
description: A continuation of BIOL 243L.   One three-hour laboratory per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Microbiology
description: An introduction to bacteria and viruses, emphasizing structure, metabolism, and pathogenesis. Discussion of infectious diseases, antigen-antibody relationships, and anti-microbial agents in chemotherapy. Not available for biology major credit.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 06/03/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Microbiology Laboratory
description: Not available for biology major credit. Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Physiology
description: Physiology of human systems especially susceptible to disturbance: immunobiology, circulation, excretion, metabolism, endocrinology, and muscle physiology. Not for biology major credit. Intended for pharmacy students.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Introduction to Environmental Biology
description: Basic ecological principles and the impacts of human population growth and technology. Not for major credit.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Introduction to Environmental Biology Laboratory
description: Demonstrations, data analyses, discussions, and films relating to human ecology, resource use, and environmental impact. Not for major credit.   Two hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Ecology and Evolution
description: Concepts of evolution, populations, and population interactions; communities and ecosystems.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Ecology and Evolution Laboratory
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations.  Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Cell and Molecular Biology
description: Principles of eukaryotic cell structure, molecular organization, and physiology. Genome organization and expression. Cell growth, division,   and cell-cell interactions.   FS: 12/07/2022.

subject: BIOL
name: Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Experiments, exercises, and demonstrations. Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Fundamental Genetics
description: Basic principles of transmission and molecular genetics; quantitative inheritance; recombination; biochemical aspects of gene function and regulation; developmental genetics and population genetics.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Fundamental Genetics Laboratory
description: Observational and experimental examination of principles of genetics and inheritance.   FS: 02/03/2021.

subject: BIOL
name: Introduction to Animal Science
description: Exploration of current careers in the animal industry including a brief overview of the sciences involved in animal production such as genetics and selection, behavior, physiology, reproduction, and nutrition of cattle (beef and dairy), horses, swine, sheep, poultry, and others.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Laboratory Teaching Experience
description: Participation in preparation and teaching of undergraduate biological sciences laboratories.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department head is required for undergraduate students.

subject: BIOL
name: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology
description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the development and functions of the nervous system, such as nervous system patterning, neuronal differentiation/migration, formation of neuronal projections, development of synapses, apoptosis, refinement of neuronal circuits, and how cells and neurons respond to signals from the environment.   FS: 06/01/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy
description: Phylogenetic and comparative aspects of anatomy, reproduction, and embryology of the vertebrates.  Three lecture hours and one three-hour laboratory period per week.   FS: 10/1/2014.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Survey of the Plant Kingdom
description: Phylogenetic survey of the major plant divisions; consideration of the structure and development of flowering plants.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Survey of the Plant Kingdom Laboratory
description: Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Medicinal Botany
description: A survey of plants affecting human health and how they are used historically and in modern times, with emphasis on the biologically active constituents.   FS: 09/09/2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Form and Function
description: Basic introduction to plants, including cellular biology, energetics, structure-function relationships, development, nutrition, and diversity.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Form and Function Laboratory
description: Illustration of principles of introductory botany and plant physiology using experiments, exercises, and demonstrations. Three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Principles of Biological Oceanography
description: Principles and methods of measuring production in the sea. Emphasis on the ocean’s role in the global carbon budget. Three lecture hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Advanced Human Physiology
description: Functional physiology of human organ systems.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Advanced Human Physiology Laboratory
description: Experiments on organ system functions using different animal models.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Advanced Human Anatomy
description: Structure, function, and development of human anatomy.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Advanced Human Anatomy Laboratory
description: Practical exercises in structure, function, and development of anatomy using digital and animal models.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Advanced Microbiology
description: The taxonomy, morphology, metabolism, genetics, and ecology of microorganisms.    FS: 09/09/2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Advanced Microbiology Laboratory
description: Practical exercises with the taxonomy, morphology, metabolism, genetics, and ecology of microorganisms.    FS: 09/09/2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Domestic Animal Nutrition
description: Elements of nutrition and animal feeding in veterinary practice.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Undergraduate Seminar in Biological Sciences
description: Student seminars and a survey of research in the fields of Biological Sciences.   Pre-requisites:BIOL 301, BIOL 302, and BIOL 303, or Instructor's Permission   FS: 11/05/2019

subject: BIOL
name: Biological Research: An Introduction
description: Methodologies of biological research with emphasis on hypothesis formation, research design, and data collection, and current issues in biology.   Two lecture and six laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Environmental Microbiology
description: An overview of the microbial world including a survey of the distribution, functioning, and diversity of microorganisms in natural systems.  Discusses the crucial roles that microorganisms play in ecosystem function, biogeochemical cycles, and environmental quality.    CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Developmental Biology
description: An introduction to how cell-cell communication, gene expression, cell division, cytoskeletal dynamics, and interactions with the extracellular matrix result in the differentiation, pattern formation, morphogenesis, and growth necessary to generate a new individual.   FS: 10/07/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Developmental Biology Laboratory I
description: Descriptive and experimental exercises related to embryology. One three-hour laboratory per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Developmental Biology II
description: Molecular aspects of development from gamete formation through tissue and organ differentiation in plants and animals. Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Developmental Biology Laboratory II
description: A series of experimentally oriented laboratory exercises will be performed. One three-hour laboratory per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Invertebrate Zoology
description: Phylogenetic and comparative aspects of anatomy, physiology, reproduction, and embryology of the invertebrates.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Development
description: Descriptive and molecular examination of the processes and mechanisms used by plants in organogenesis, differentiation, and morphogenesis.   Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/07/2022.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Developmental Laboratory
description: Experiments utilizing a genetic approach to the study of plant development. Three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Mycology
description: Taxonomy and morphology of fungi; cultivation, life histories, and economic importance; all classes and major orders considered.   Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.   .

subject: BIOL
name: Marine Plants
description: Diversity, distribution, physiology, ecology, evolution, and economic importance of marine algal, seagrass, and mangrove communities.   Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week. Scheduled field trips are required.     CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: The Fall Flora
description: Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: The Spring Flora
description: Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: The Summer Flora
description: Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Histology
description: An introduction to the tissues that make up the human body. The microscopic anatomy of tissues is examined and discussed in terms of function and physiology.  Three lecture hours and four laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Parasitology
description: Parasites of biological, economic, and public health importance.  Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Animal Behavior
description: A comparative survey of behavior patterns of animals from protists to humans and the physiological mechanisms underlying behavior.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Animal Behavior Laboratory
description: Observational and experimental methods used in classifying animal behavior patterns and in determining underlying control mechanisms.   One three-hour laboratory per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Fishery Management
description: Management and conservation of aquatic and marine resources, with emphasis on fisheries. Data procurement and analysis; commercial and recreational fisheries; sociological, political, legal, and environmental factors that affect fishery management; and fish biodiversity.   FS: 11/7/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Ichthyology
description: Phylogeny, morphology, behavior, and ecology of fishes.  Three lecture and 3 laboratory hours plus three field trips to be arranged.   FS: 11/7/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Aquaculture
description: Introduction to the practical and scientific aspects of the commercial culture of freshwater and marine organisms.  Three lecture hours per week. One all-day field trip required.    CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Behavior of Marine Organisms
description: The identification of behavioral adaptations of estuarine and marine organisms: their ecology, physiology, development, and evolutionary history; field observations.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biochemistry
description: Description of biological macromolecules and major metabolic pathways.   FS: 2/1/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Experiments and demonstrations illustrating the principles of biochemistry.   Three laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Comparative Physiology
description: An integrative and comparative study of the structure, function, and evolution of the physiological systems of animals. Three lecture hours per week.    FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Comparative Physiology Laboratory
description: Laboratory exercises to illustrate principles from BIOL 543. Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology I
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry. First semester of a two-semester course.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 2/1/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology II
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry and molecular biology.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 2/1/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Physiology
description: A general survey of the major physiological processes in plants.  Two lecture and four laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Bacteriology
description: Introduction to bacteria and viruses emphasizing ultrastructure, physiology, genetics, and growth. Discussion of public health, industrial, and environmental microbiology.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Bacteriology Laboratory
description: Three laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Population Genetics
description: An introduction to the principles of population genetics, with emphasis on the origin, maintenance, and significance of genetic variation in natural populations.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Genomics
description: Current concepts and applications of genomics, addressing questions from throughout biological inquiry.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Stem Cells and The Physiological Environment
description: Discussion of how physiological factors, like nutritional status, influence systemic signals to alter stem cell activity, and the physiological stimuli that impact stem cell activity in a variety of organisms (from worms to humans).   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Principles of Ecology
description: Interactions of organisms and the environment; ecosystem structure and functions.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Principles of Ecology Laboratory
description: Three hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Conservation Biology
description: Principles of conservation biology. Importance of biodiversity, causes of decline and extinction, and restoration and conversation policy in terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.   ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Freshwater Ecology
description: Quantitative study of the population, community and evolutionary ecology of freshwater habitats (lakes, ponds, rivers, streams, wetlands).    Includes mandatory field trips.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Marine Conservation Biology
description: Exploration of how human activities affect marine natural populations, species, communities and ecosystems, including threats to biodiversity; approaches to marine conservation; and ecological and evolutionary responses to anthropogenic disturbance.   FS: 12/03/2014.   ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Marine Ecology
description: Structure, dynamics, and interactions between populations and communities in marine ecosystems.  Attendance at designated departmental seminars is required.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Marine Ecology Laboratory
description: Laboratory and field exercises in coastal environments. Three hours per week plus field trips.

subject: BIOL
name: Marine Fisheries Ecology
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the distribution, reproduction, survival, and historical variation of the principal commercial marine fisheries.    FS: 12/03/2014.   ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Ecology of Coral Reefs
description: Structure, productivity, and biodiversity of coral reefs, emphasizing their sensitivity, stability, and sustainability. Taught as an extended field experience with daily lectures and guided research activities.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Genomic Data Science
description: This course focuses on quantitative knowledge for interdisciplinary applications in genetics as well as hands-on experience in analyzing genetic data. In this course, students will have programming exercises in using analysis tools to conduct genome-wide analysis, annotation, and interpretation of genetic data using R/Bioconductor packages.    FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Topics in Biology
description: Current developments in biological sciences. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Hallmarks of Cancer
description: Survey of current concepts regarding the molecular and genetic factors that regulate the origin and progression of cancer. Readings based on current primary literature.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Virology - Classical and Emerging Concepts
description: Advanced study of viruses with regard to biochemical, molecular, pathological, epidemiological, and biotechnological aspects. Focus on animal viruses with particular emphasis on human pathogens.   FS: 12/01/202.

subject: BIOL
name: Stem Cell Biology
description: Focuses on the understanding of how stem cells can be used to make fundamental biological discoveries with a special focus in neuroscience.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Immunobiology
description: Basic immunological concepts including antibody structure, function, and genetics; cellular immunology; transplantation; hypersensitivity; autoimmunity; and immunity to infectious diseases.   FS: 11/04/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Medical Mycology
description: Advanced study of infectious diseases caused by fungi.  Etiology, symptoms, and treatment of fungi related illnesses.   FS: 03/05/2014.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Marine Phytoplankton
description: Examines the physiology and ecology of phytoplankton, including environmental controls on community composition, primary productivity, and detection and characterization of water quality (eutrophication) and harmful algal blooms.    FS: 11/06/2013.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biology of Birds
description: Biology of birds at molecular, organismal, and population levels, emphasizing unique adaptations of the class of Aves.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biology of Neurological Diseases
description: Advances in molecular and cellular neurobiology that bring new understanding for human neurological disease.   FS: 06/01/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Neurophysiology
description: Descriptive and experimental aspects of the neural basis of behavior, emphasizing cellular and molecular mechanisms. Two lecture and six laboratory hours per week.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 11/2/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Microbial Ecology
description: Interactions of microorganisms with each other, with more complex organisms, and with their environments.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biophysical Ecology
description: This course examines how the mechanisms by which animals and plants interact with their physical environments influence organismal physiology.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biochemical Evolution
description: Advanced study of related aspects of biological evolution.  Rose of life from physical and chemical precursors, biochemical basis of adaptation to ecological pressures, and biochemical aspects of the origins and maintenance of biodiversity.   FS: 10/1/2014.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Limnology
description: A study of the aquatic environment and its biota. Three lecture and four laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Evolutionary Biology
description: An advanced course in evolutionary biology, including natural selection, neutral evolution, molecular evolution population genetics, quantitative genetics, sexual selection, speciation, human evolution, and the evolution of disease.     FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Bioinformatics
description: Studies of the principles of genetics and molecular biology as applied to adaptive evolution of genes and genomes.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Speciation
description: Speciation as the source of biological diversity. Analysis of genetic and ecological models of speciation using primary literature.   FS: 12/01/2021.

subject: BIOL
name: Biotechnology
description: Studies in molecular biology and genetics with emphasis on the use of newly developed techniques in biotechnology.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Experimental Biotechnology
description: Techniques used in biotechnology will be employed in the context of an experimental project.  Twelve laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Biology of Mammals
description: Evolution, systematics, genetics, ecology, and adaptation of mammals. Emphasis on native South Carolina species.  Two lectures and one two-hour laboratory per week, plus five field trips to be arranged.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Signal Transduction and Pathogenesis
description: Signaling pathways involved in human diseases, such as cancer, AIDS, autoimmune diseases and diabetes, and cellular processes involving apoptosis, cell cycle, cell-cell adhesion, growth factors, hormones, G protein-couples receptors, cytokines and immune response.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Human Molecular Genetics
description: Molecular mechanisms underlying gene action and differentiation in man; the genetic bases for human variability and inborn metabolic errors leading to inherited diseases.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Molecular and Genetic Mechanisms of Disease Pathogenesis
description: An advanced examination of the molecular mechanisms underlying gene action in humans. Current literature illustrating the genotype-phenotype   relationship in human disease pathogenesis will be discussed.    CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Metabolic Biochemistry of Human Disease
description: Core concepts of biochemistry as applied to human health and disease.   FS: 06/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Ecology
description: Structure and dynamics of plant populations and communities, including life histories, adaptations, and plant interactions.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Ecology
description: Laboratory and field exercises in plant ecology. Four hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Plant Responses to the Environment
description: Physiological, molecular, and genetic examination of induced plant responses to various biotic and abiotic environmental stresses.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOL
name: Ultramicroscopy
description: Theoretical and practical aspects of scanning and transmission electron microscopy, digital image acquisition and energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy.  Two lecture and one laboratory hour per week, plus a research project to be arranged.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOS
name: Introduction to Biostatistical Modeling
description: Statistical modeling, primarily using applications in public health. Measures of agreement, principles of statistical inference, correlation, simple and multiple linear regression, categorical independent variables, interaction, repeated measures, and logistic regression.   FS: 04/01/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOS
name: Independent Study
description: Enrollment and topic to be approved in advance by advisor and instructor. May be repeated.   CL: 2020.

subject: BIOS
name: Introduction to Biostatistics
description: Health-related statistical applications. Descriptive statistics, probability, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, regression, correlation, ANOVA.    May not be used as part of a degree program in epidemiology or biostatistics.  Three lecture hours and one laboratory hour per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Introduction to topics comprising the field of Biomedical Engineering, including their ethical impacts. Familiarization with resources and basic skills necessary to succeed in this major and field.    FS: 12/2/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Fundamentals of Biomedical Systems
description: Fundamentals of static equilibrium, free body diagrams, force and momentum balances; viscoelastic mechanical behavior and models of viscoelasticity; introduction to linear circuit analysis.   FS: 04/05/2023.

subject: BMEN
name: Cellular and Molecular Biology with Engineering Applications
description: Introduction to molecular, cellular, and physical biology principles and concepts and application of engineering principles to further the understanding of biological systems.  Protein and nucleic acid structure and function; DNA replication, mutations, and repair; transcription, translation, and post-translational processing; cellular organization; molecular transport and trafficking; and cellular models.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Introduction to Biomechanics
description: Mathematical and theoretical analysis of the mechanical properties and functions of materials, including those of biological origin and clinical relevance.  Stress, strain, mechanical properties of materials, axial loading, torsion, bending, and stress/strain transformations. Application of the categories and methodology of solid mechanics to study biological tissues and events.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Introduction to Biomaterials
description: Properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, natural materials and composites; methods to modify surface and bulk properties of biomaterials; mechanisms of degradation in physiological environments; cell- and tissue-biomaterial interactions; host response to implanted biomaterials; blood-biomaterial interactions; rational design of biomaterials for specific biomedical applications.   FS: 12/01/2021.

subject: BMEN
name: Thermodynamics of Biomolecular Systems
description: First, second, and third law of thermodynamics; free energy and chemical equilibrium in biological processes; phase equilibrium for biomedical systems; energy and metabolism; membrane potentials and depolarization.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Professional Development and Ethics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Analysis and discussion of biomedical industries, standards, regulations, products, and patents. Ethical issues associated with research, introduction of new products, animal subjects, and human subjects.   FS: 10/05/2022.

subject: BMEN
name: Professional Development and Ethics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Analysis and discussion of industries, products, patents, industrial inventiveness, and biomedical research. Ethical issues associated with research, introduction of new products, animal subjects, and human subjects.    FS: 12/07/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Biomonitoring and Electrophysiology
description: Basic electric circuits and equivalent cell model circuits used in biomonitoring and electrophysiology.  Ohm’s and Kirchoff’s Laws.  Applications of electrical components, such as operations amplifiers, filter, and Wheastone bridge, in biomonitoring and electrophysiology.  Origins of bioelectricity.  Biopotential and electrochemistry including Nernst and Goldman-Hudgkin-Katz equations for describing membrane potential of nerve and muscle cells.  Ion transport involved in maintaining cell pH, action potential, muscle contraction, sensory perception.    FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Infectious Disease & Immunology for Biomedical Engineers
description: Qualitative and quantitative aspects of infectious diseases; principles of diagnosis and control. Elements of human immunological response and immune disorders; influence on biomedical engineering of explants and implants.    CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Human Anatomy and Physiology for Biomedical Engineers
description: Foundations for biomedical engineering with a focus on human anatomy and physiology.  Introduction to the inter-relationships between tissue/organ structure and function; demonstration of how an engineering approach can promote understanding of these relationships.  Recent biomedical engineering advances and their relations to underlying anatomy and physiology.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Medical Microbiology for Biomedical Engineers
description: Qualitative and quantitative aspects of human system based medical microbiology; principles of diagnosis and control of representative human diseases.  Elements of human immunological response and immune disorders.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Biotransport
description: Basics of convective and diffusive transport applied to biological and biomedical systems. The effect of fluid flow and mass transport upon biochemical interactions.  Scaling and design of biotransport systems.   FS: 09/14/2022.

subject: BMEN
name: Biomedical Instrumentation
description: Sensing and measurement of biophysical and biochemical properties and signals in the human body for quantitative molecular, cell, and tissue analysis. Overview on the theory, design and application of common biomedical instrumentation used for diagnosis, treatment, and scientific study of physiological parameters in clinical medicine and biomedical research.   FS: 09/14/2022.

subject: BMEN
name: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory I
description: Introduction to laboratory techniques and tools used for physiological measurements in biomedical engineering, with focus on biological, physical, and biomaterial methods. Data processing and analysis, as well as effective communication of results in written and oral form.   FS: 12/2/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory II
description: Introduction to laboratory techniques and tools used for physiological measurements in biomedical engineering, with focus on measurement of biosignals and common analytical methods employed in biomedical research and clinical settings. Data processing and analysis, as well as effective communication of results in written and oral form.   FS: 09/14/2022.

subject: BMEN
name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering for Undergraduates
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topic varies.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Kinetics in Biomolecular Systems
description: Kinetic theory applied to biomedical systems, including enzymatic reactions, cell growth, and kinetic models of biological systems.   FS: 12/01/2021.

subject: BMEN
name: Fundamentals of Biochemical Engineering
description: Biological systems are used in chemical industries for a wide variety of applications, including the formation of important products (e.g. pharmaceuticals), sensor technology, degradation, and waste water treatment. This class will provide an overview of materials needed to investigate and model biosystems.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Modeling and Simulation of Biomedical Systems
description: Introduction to modern computational modeling tools used in biomedical engineering. Analysis, visualization and image processing using engineering software as applied to problems of interest in biomedical engineering.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Senior Biomedical Engineering Design I
description: Integrated team work/project management, "voice of the patient", design specifications, design functions, design concepts, economic factors, concept selection and product architecture. The initial feasibility study, selection of the final design approach, and preliminary specifications are required by the end of the semester.    FS: 09/08/2021.

subject: BMEN
name: Senior Biomedical Engineering Design II
description: Design for manufacturability, ergonomic and aesthetic considerations, prototype construction and testing, fabrication and biological testing of tissue engineered constructs, statistical methods/design of experiments, ethics/product liability and social/environmental impact. The final engineering design (specifications, drawings, bill of materials, including assessment of economics) will be completed by the end of the semester. Both written and oral reports are to be provided.   FS: 09/14/2022.

subject: BMEN
name: Independent Research
description: Individual investigation or studies of special topics.  A maximum of 3 credits may be applied to Biomedical Engineering program requirements.   Contract approval by instructor, department, and college is required.   FS: 09/08/2021.

subject: BMEN
name: Micro/nanofluidics and Lab-on-a-Chip
description: Basic fluid mechanics, capillary, drop and micro/nanoparticle, electrokinetics; micropump, mixer, preconcentrator, electrophoresis, microactuator and particle manipulator; sensors for pressure, velocity, concentration, temperature in environmental monitoring/biodefence, clinical diagnostics, drug discovery/delivery.   FS: 12/02/2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Bio Nano/Micro Electro-Mechanical Systems
description: Fundamentals of nano- and microfabrication, metrology and their applications in biomedical engineering and science. The fabrication covers photolithography, nano/microfabrication for nano/microstructures, etching and additive techniques, MEMS integration and packaging, etc. Metrology focuses on characterization of nanostructures with imaging technologies.   FS: 12/02/2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Delivery of Bioactive Agents
description: Routes of administration; mechanisms of drug absorption and biological barriers; pharmacokinetic modeling of drug distribution; drug excretion and biotransformation; design and evaluation of controlled release systems, targeted release systems, and responsive release systems.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Immunoengineering
description: Engineering approaches to study and control immune reactions and their applications in therapy and diagnostics for infectious disease, cancer, allergy, autoimmunity, and transplantation.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Cardiovascular System: From Development to Disease
description: Survey of cardiovascular development, anatomy, physiology and pathology.  Recent advances in our understanding of the basic mechanisms of congenital cardiovascular defects and cardiovascular disease. Engineering principles, detection and treatment of cardiovascular defects.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Advanced Biomechanics
description: Mathematical and theoretical analysis of the mechanical properties and functions of soft biological tissues to include arterial vessels.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Tissue Engineering
description: Molecular basis of bioregenerative engineering; biomaterial design; biocompatibility assessment; cell isolation and characterization; rapid prototyping, scaffold fabrication, and biofabrication; protein and gene delivery; bioreactor design; transport in biological tissues; applications of tissue engineering in regenerative medicine.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Engineering of Soft Materials
description: Introductory overview of fundamental concepts in science and engineering of soft materials; the relation between microstructure and macroscopic behavior in a variety of soft matter systems; key applications in chemical and biomedical engineering.   FS: 12/01/2021.

subject: BMEN
name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. May be repeated as topic varies.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Modeling and Simulation of Biomedical System
description: Analytical and quantitative techniques applied to engineering problems in biomedical transport, tissue mechanics, celluar and organ physiology, and control of medical devices.   CL: 2020.

subject: BMEN
name: Anatomy and Physiology for Biomedical Engineers
description: An examination of human biological structure and function from an engineering perspective. Engineering principles will be used to analyze anatomical structures and physiological functions at the tissue, organ, and systems levels.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Fundamental Chemistry I
description: A science elective surveying inorganic and solution chemistry. First of a terminal two-semester sequence. Three lecture, one recitation, and two laboratory hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Fundamental Chemistry II
description: An introductory survey of organic and biochemistry. Three lecture, one recitation, and two laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Chemistry and Modern Society I
description: A conceptual and qualitative approach to chemistry, its evolution, achievements, and goals and its impact on technology, the environment, and modern life and thought. (Specifically designed for non-science majors.)  Three lecture and three laboratory hours per week.   FS: 02/05/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Chemistry and Modern Society II
description: A continuation of Chemistry 105.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Chemistry and Modern Society II Laboratory
description: Laboratory associated with CHEM 106.  Three hours of laboratory per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Forensic Chemistry
description: Surveys chemical aspects of criminal investigation and adjudication including drug, arson, DNA, paint, and fiber identification.   FS: 02/01/2023.

subject: CHEM
name: Introduction to Forensic Science Laboratory
description: An analytical approach to surveys of criminal investigation and adjudication of crime scene analysis and collection and preservation of evidence. Analysis will include but not be limited to drug, arson, DNA, fingerprints, blood splatter, and fiber identification. Note: Three laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/07/2022.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry I
description: Survey of the principles that underlie all chemistry with applications illustrating these principles.  Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry I Lab
description: Introduction to the principles and techniques of experimental chemistry with emphasis on formula investigations, equations, elementary statistics, and chemical reactivity.   FS: 12/02/2020.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry II
description: Continuation of CHEM 111. Special emphasis on chemical equilibrium. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.   FS: 12/07/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: General Chemistry II Lab
description: Continuation of CHEM 111L with emphasis on solution properties, kinetics, equilibrium, acids and bases, and qualitative analysis.   FS: 09/12/2013.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Computational Chemistry I
description: Introduction to the use of computers in solving chemical problems. One discussion and two laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Principles of Chemistry I
description: Advanced general chemistry I. Atoms and chemical bonds.  Three lecture hours, one recitation hour, and three laboratory hours per week. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 111 and CHEM 141.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Principles of Chemistry II
description: Advanced general chemistry II. Chemical kinetics, equilibria, and thermodynamics.  Three lecture hours, one recitation hour, and three laboratory hours per week. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 112 and CHEM 142.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Computational Chemistry II
description: A continuation of CHEM 118, with applications to more advanced chemical problems. One discussion and two laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Quantitative Analysis
description: Gravimetric, volumetric, and introductory instrumental analysis. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Quantitative Analysis Laboratory
description: Three laboratory hours per week. Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 321L and CHEM 322L.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Analytical Chemistry
description: Qualitative analysis, quantitative analysis, fundamental or method analysis, and molecular characterization.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Analytical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Laboratory skill building in analytical techniques. Applications of stoichiometry, spectroscopy, phase transfer, electrochemistry and kinetics.   Credit cannot be received for both CHEM 321L and CHEM 322L.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Essentials of Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Laboratory safety, syntheses, separation, and purification of carbon compounds. For non-majors.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Essentials of Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
description: Continuation of CHEM 331L. Spectroscopic identification of carbon compounds. For non-majors.  Three lab hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry I
description: Contemporary theories, nomenclature, reactions, mechanisms, and syntheses of carbon compounds.  Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Comprehensive Organic Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Laboratory safety, synthesis, separation, and purification of carbon compounds. Required for chemistry majors. Six laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Organic Chemistry II
description: Continuation of CHEM 333. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Comprehensive Organic Chemistry Laboratory II
description: Continuation of CHEM 333L. Spectroscopic identification of carbon compounds. Required for chemistry majors. Six laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Elementary Biophysical Chemistry
description: A non-calculus approach to the study of the principles of physical chemistry emphasizing their application to significant biochemical and biological systems. Chemical thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium, solution chemistry, the structure of macromolecules, and acid-base properties of biomolecules. Credit for a degree will not be given for both CHEM 340 and CHEM 541.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: Student seminars and a survey of biochemical and molecular biology research at the University of South Carolina. Required of all biochemistry majors.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Independent Study
description: Contract Required.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Industrial Chemistry Capstone Experience
description: Prepares students for future roles in chemical industry or graduate school and provides career-enhancing interpersonal skills, including team-building, public speaking, resume preparation, and interviewing.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester.  Nine hours of library and laboratory per week.  Contract Required.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester.  Nine hours of library and laboratory per week. Contract Required.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester.  Nine hours of library and laboratory per week.  Contract Required.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the methods of chemical research. A written report on work accomplished is required at the end of each semester. Nine hours of library and laboratory per week. Contract Required.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Inorganic Chemistry
description: Consideration of atomic structure, valence, complex compounds, and systematic study of the periodic table.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Comprehensive Organic Chemistry III
description: Selected organic reactions from synthetic and mechanistic viewpoints. For Undergraduate Credit Only.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Physical Chemistry
description: Chemical thermodynamics and kinetics.  For Undergraduate Credit Only.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Applications of physical chemical techniques.  Five laboratory hours and one recitation hour per week.   FS: 12/02/15.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Physical Chemistry
description: Spectroscopy, statistical mechanics, and chemical applications of quantum mechanics.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Physical Chemistry Laboratory
description: Applications of physical chemical techniques. Five laboratory hours and one recitation hour per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Physical Biochemistry
description: A survey of physical methods essential for studies of biomacromolecules. Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/07/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Biochemistry
description: Description of biological macromolecules and major metabolic pathways. Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Experiments and demonstrations illustrating the principles of biochemistry. Three laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology I
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry. First semester of a two-semester course. Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology II
description: Essentials of modern biochemistry and molecular biology.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/07/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Special Topics in Inorganic Chemistry
description: Current developments in inorganic chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies by title and will be announced in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for credit.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Instrumental Analysis
description: Chemical instrumentation including electronics, signal processing, statistical analysis, molecular/atomic spectroscopy, electrochemical methods, chromatography, and mass spectrometry. Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Instrumental Analysis Lab
description: Methods, principles and strategies for chemical instrumentation in analysis. Chemical instrumentation laboratory with environmental, forensic, and biotechnology applications.  Three laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Forensic Analytical Chemistry
description: Analytical chemical methods in forensic science, including gathering of evidence, toxicology, drug identification, analysis of trace evidence, arson analysis, and DNA/serology. Three lecture hours and three laboratory hours per week.   FS: 12/07/2022.

subject: CHEM
name: Introductory Environmental Chemistry
description: Study of the chemical reactions and processes that affect the fate and transport of organic chemicals in the environment.  Three lecture hours per week.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Aquatic Chemistry
description: Study of the chemical reactions and processes affecting the distribution of chemical species in natural systems.  Three lecture hours per week.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Special Topics in Analytical Chemistry
description: Current developments in inorganic chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies by title and will be announced in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for credit.    CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Introduction to Polymer Synthesis
description: Special emphasis on the modern synthesis of polymeric materials. Definitions, characterization, and applications of polymers will be briefly presented.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
description: Current developments in organic chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. May be repeated as content varies by title.    FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Computational Chemistry
description: This course is designed to familiarize students with theory and use of modern electronic structure codes, as well as to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills and to improve computer literacy.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Materials Chemistry
description: Introduction to materials science; structural and electronic description of inorganic-based solids; experimental techniques in materials chemistry; interfacial energetics and optoelectronic processes at metal and semiconductor surfaces.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
description: Current developments in physical chemistry. Readings and research on selected topics. Course content varies by title and will be announced in the schedule of classes. May be repeated for credit.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Metabolic Biochemistry of Human Disease
description: Core concepts of biochemistry as applied to human health and disease.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHEM
name: Special Topics in Biochemistry
description: Selected topics in the field of biochemistry. May be repeated as content varies by title.    FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Introduction to Chinese Calligraphy
description: Five hundred of the most commonly used Chinese characters. Emphasis is on the phonetic and significant elements common to large groups of ideograms.

subject: CHIN
name: Elementary Chinese Mandarin
description: Grammar and practical vocabulary necessary for fundamental communication skills. Assumes no prior experience in the language.    CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Basic Proficiency in Mandarin Chinese
description: Practice and further development of essential listening, reading, speaking, and writing skills. Admission only by successful completion of Chinese 121.    CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese
description: Continued practice of basic sentence patterns used in modern speech with increased emphasis on reading and acquisition of additional characters.

subject: CHIN
name: Intermediate Mandarin Chinese II
description: Continued practice of basic sentence patterns used in modern speech with increased emphasis on reading and acquisition of additional characters.

subject: CHIN
name: Chinese Culture, Tradition, and Modern Societies
description: Introduction to Chinese culture, heritage, and modern societies. Readings selected from printed and online sources. Taught in English.

subject: CHIN
name: Advanced intermediate Mandarin Chinese I
description: Provides advanced intermediate training in spoken and written Chinese. By increasing students’ vocabulary and knowledge of sentence patterns, the course focuses on speaking and writing in coherent, well-formed paragraphs.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Advanced Intermediate Mandarin Chinese II
description: Continues advanced intermediate training in spoken and written Chinese. Attention is given to complex grammatical patterns, discourse characteristics, and discussions of cultural topics.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Women in China
description: Introduces the connection between gender and the Chinese national imagination. Readings include cultural and historical documents that purport to explain the experience of women in China. Readings in English. Taught in English.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Introduction to Premodern Chinese Literature
description: An introduction to the most important works, authors, genres, and themes of Chinese literature from the first millennium B.C.E. to 1911.    FS: 6/7/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Modern Chinese Literature
description: Readings of canonical texts from modern Chinese literature. A focus is on the role of literature and other cultural documents in the imagination of China as a modern nation. Readings and discussion in English.

subject: CHIN
name: Screening China
description: Survey of Chinese language cinema. Chinese film history and vocabulary with which to discuss film texts. Covers classic leftwing cinema, Hong Kong martial arts films, as well as the Hong Kong, Taiwan, and PRC New Waves. Taught in English. Films subtitled.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Selected Topics
description: Intensive study in selected authors or literary movements of China, including cultural aspects. May be repeated for credit under different titles. Taught in English.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and department chair is required for undergraduate students.

subject: CHIN
name: Advanced Chinese I
description: Acquisition of advanced grammar and vocabulary. Emphasis on building oral proficiency in professional settings.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Advanced Chinese II
description: Continued acquisition of advanced grammar and vocabulary. Emphasis on expanding communicative abilities in a wider variety of interpersonal situations.   CL: 2020.

subject: CHIN
name: Advanced Special Topics in Chinese Studies
description: Advanced special topics in Chinese studies. May be repeated as content varies by title.   FS: 12/02/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Introduction to Classical Mythology
description: Major gods, goddesses, heroes, and heroines of classical mythology as portrayed in major literary works; the function of myth in society and its relevance to modern life.   CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Medical and Scientific Terminology
description: Greek and Latin elements in the formation of medical and scientific vocabulary; designed for students intending to enter the scientific and health professions. No previous knowledge of Greek or Latin required.

subject: CLAS
name: Sport and Combat in the Ancient World
description: This course is designed to introduce students to the importance of competition in the military and private spheres of the Greco-Roman world, a dominant legacy of antiquity.

subject: CLAS
name: Ancient Philosophy
description: An introduction to the work of ancient philosophers, with special emphasis on Plato and Aristotle.   CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Greek and Roman Philosophy after Aristotle
description: Problems such as hedonism, providence, belief and evidence, and mysticism, as they appear in the writings of Epicureans, Stoics, Skeptics, and Plotinus.

subject: CLAS
name: Greece and Rome in Film and Popular Culture
description: Representations of antiquity in cinema, television, and other contemporary media, with emphasis on Hollywood’s reception of Greek and Roman history.   CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Sexuality and Gender in Ancient Greece
description: Gender roles, standards of sexual behavior, evidence for women’s lives, as manifested in ancient Greek literary and archaeological evidence; attitudes toward homosexuality; the modern media’s representation of famous Greeks.   FS: 12/05/2018.

subject: CLAS
name: Sexuality, Gender, and Power in Ancient Rome
description: Sexuality as a social construct exemplified in standards of sexual behavior in ancient Rome and their reinforcement of the ruling ideology; feminine virtue, definitions of manliness, attitudes toward homosexuality.   FS: 12/05/2018.

subject: CLAS
name: Greek Civilization on Site
description: Introduction to the history and culture of ancient Greece, combined with an excursion of Greece.  Topics include: Mycenaean Greece and the world of Homer, Archaic Greece, oikos and polis, interaction with the Near East, Athens in the 5th and 4th centruy BCE, Greek religion, ancient Greek society.   FS: 10/5/2011.    CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Special Topics in Classical Humanities
description: Intensive study of one topic per semester dealing with ancient contributions to Western civilization. Not for Greek or Latin major credit. In English. May be repeated as content varies by title.   CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Classical Roots of US Constitution
description: Study of the impact of the culture of Greece and Rome on the founding fathers of the American Revolution.   FS: 12/01/2021.

subject: CLAS
name: Greek Art and Archaeology
description: A survey of ancient architecture, painting, and sculpture 2000-160 B.C.

subject: CLAS
name: Pompeii: Daily Life in a Roman Town
description: This course uses the rich archaeological resource of the city of Pompeii to explore daily life in Ancient Rome. Using both material and written sources, students will learn about how people of all social classes lived in the public and private spaces of Pompeii.   FS: 02/02/2022.

subject: CLAS
name: Classical Origins of Western Medical Ethics
description: Examination of ancient Greek and Roman philosophical, medical, and literary works (in English) as sources for the origins of medical ethics.   Priority enrollment for Medical Humanities students.   CL: 2020.

subject: CLAS
name: Between Magic and Method: Ancient Medicine
description: Introduction to ancient medicine: science and art, theory and practice, healing and predicting.  Topics include Medicine before Hippocrates, Hippocratic medicine, holism, naturalism, medicine, religion and magic, medicine and scientific explanation, Hellenistic medicine and methodology, Galenic medicine.

subject: CLAS
name: Rise and Fall of the Athenian Empire
description: Athenian History from Persian Wars through Peloponnesian War.   FS: 10/05/2022.

subject: CLAS
name: The Caesars: Rome's First Family
description: Study of Rome’s imperial family from Julius Caesar until the death of Nero.   FS: 10/05/2022.

subject: CLAS
name: Greek and Latin Literature in Translation
description: A comparative survey of Greek and Latin masters.

subject: CLAS
name: Classical Drama
description: Representative plays by Greek and Roman dramatists.   FS: 09/08/2021.

subject: CLAS
name: Rhetoric and the Ancient Roots of Modern Life
description: Classical rhetoric and its ongoing influence in the modern world, emphasizing how the study and use of language in ancient Greece and Rome continue to shape modern communication.

subject: CLAS
name: Classical Mythology
description: The major Greek and Roman myths, with emphasis on their meaning, functions, and influence on ancient and later Western culture.

subject: CLAS
name: Classics of Western Literary Theory
description: Problems of literary theory in texts from the ancients to the 17th century, with an emphasis on the classical tradition.   CL: 2020.

subject: COLA
name: Interdisciplinary Special Topics in the Liberal Arts: Social Sciences
description: Interdisciplinary special topics emphasizing the social sciences. May be repeated as content varies by title and section.   FS: 09/11/2013.   CL: 2020.

subject: COLA
name: Internship: Community Engagement
description: Supervised experience in the United States. Contract approval by instructor, advisor, and Assistant Dean for Academic Studies is required for undergraduate students.  Minimum GPA of 2.5 required or permission of instructor of record.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: COLA
name: Internship: Global Community Engagement
description: Supervised experience either while student is studying abroad or when offered an internship by an appropriate entity outside the United states.  Contract approval by instructor and Assistant Dean for Academic Studies is required.  Minimum GPA requirement of 2.5 or higher or permission of the instructor of record.    FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: COLA
name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
description: Advanced reading and research on selected interdisciplinary topics in the liberal arts. Course content varies and will be announced in the schedule of classes by title. Open only to juniors and seniors with consent of instructor.   CL: 2020.

subject: COLA
name: Interdisciplinary Undergraduate Research
description: Supervised research experience in various interdiscsiplinary topics.   FS: 12/01/201.

subject: COMD
name: Public Health Perspective in Communication Sciences and Disorders
description: Public health issues related to speech, language, and hearing from local, national and global perspective in historical context.   Special permission required by department.   CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Directed Study in Speech and Language Pathology
description: Directed readings and/or research in speech pathology.   FS: 10/02/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology
description: Human communication disorders with an overview of prevention and treatment programs.   FS: 09/14/2022.

subject: COMD
name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech and Hearing Mechanisms
description: An intensive study of the anatomy and physiology of the speech and hearing mechanisms.

subject: COMD
name: Anatomy and Physiology of the Auditory and Vestibular System
description: Detailed examination of the anatomy and physiology of the auditory and vestibular system.   CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Language Theory and Phonetics
description: Study of language theory and international phonetics alphabet transcription.

subject: COMD
name: Introduction to Clinical Procedures in Speech Pathology
description: Diagnostic and therapeutic programs for the communicatively handicapped will be observed in the public school and various rehabilitative settings. Discussion and study of basic therapeutic theories and procedures utilized in speech therapy. Introduction to phonetics or equivalent or permission of instructor.   CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Selected Topics
description: Presentation of current experimental or innovative programs in diagnosis and treatment of the communicatively impaired. Course is designed to update the practicing clinician in specific areas of expertise. May be repeated for credit. Individual topics to be announced by title. Permission of instructor.    CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Disorders of Articulation: Evaluation and Therapy
description: The diagnosis and treatment of articulation problems in children and adults, including analysis of current research in testing and therapy for articulation disorders.   FS: 03/04/2015.   CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Principles of Audiology
description: Basic anatomy and psycho-physics of hearing, the pathologies of hearing loss, introduction to identification procedures including organization of hearing conservation programs and practice in pure-tone audiometry, and impact of hearing loss on preschool and school-age children and educational, psychological, and medical aspects of habilitation.

subject: COMD
name: Observation of Speech Language Pathology
description: Introduction to the clinical process through observation of various diagnostic reports and intervention programs included.   CL: 2020.

subject: COMD
name: Introduction to Language Development
description: The language acquisition process in normal children, including the development of semantics, morphology, syntax, phonology, and pragmatics; American dialects and bilingualism.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Values and Ethics in Literature
description: Analysis of major works of world literature focusing on values, ethics, and social responsibility.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: World Literature
description: Selected masterpieces of world literature from antiquity to the present.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: What is Comparative Literature
description: Introduction to ways of reading and comparing literatures drawn from diverse languages and cultures.   FS: 09/11/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Great Books of the Western World I
description: European masterpieces from antiquity to the beginning of the Renaissance.   FS: 12/05/2018.

subject: CPLT
name: Great Books of the Western World II
description: European masterpieces from the Renaissance to the present.   FS: 12/05/2018.

subject: CPLT
name: Great Books of the Eastern World
description: Classical and contemporary poetry and prose of the Middle and Far East.   FS: 12/05/2018.

subject: CPLT
name: Epic to Romance
description: Comprehensive exploration of medieval and other pre-Renaissance literature using texts representative of the evolution of dominant literary forms.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: The Renaissance
description: Literature of the Renaissance, in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: The Enlightenment
description: Literature of the Enlightenment in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Romanticism
description: Literature of Romanticism, in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Realism
description: Literature of Realism in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Modernism
description: Literature of Modernism in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Postmodernism
description: Literature of Postmodernism in its cultural contexts, explored through representative works.   FS: 12/05/2018.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Topics in Comparative Literary Relations
description: Topics involving two or more national literatures. Topics to be announced in master schedule by title.   CL: 2020.

subject: CPLT
name: Special Topics in Comparative Studies in Film and Media
description: Topics in film and media from an international perspective.  National cinematic traditions are compared and contrasted. May be repeated as content varies by title.    ACAF 2.03: 07/05/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: The American Criminal Justice System
description: Survey of crime and societal responses to crime, including law enforcement, courts, corrections, and the juvenile justice system.   FS: 06/12/2013.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Research Methods in Criminology and Criminal Justice
description: Introduction to the practice of social research in criminology and criminal justice settings.

subject: CRJU
name: Ethics in Criminal Justice
description: Examination of ethical issues in the criminal justice system.   FS: 11/06/2021.

subject: CRJU
name: History of Crime and Punishment
description: An exploration of the evolution of global practices related to enforcing conformity with societal norms. Examines legal codes, philosophies, and technological devices associated with crime and punishment throughout history.   FS: 02/01/2023.

subject: CRJU
name: Criminal Procedure
description: Overview of the constitutional restraints on the investigation, detention, prosecution and adjudication of criminal defendants. Coverage of Supreme Court decisions involving the 4th, 5th, and 6th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution.   FS: 11/03/2021.

subject: CRJU
name: Policing
description: Current and historical perspectives on American policing.   FS: 10/04/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Corrections
description: Current and historical perspectives on incarceration and its alternatives.

subject: CRJU
name: Criminal Courts
description: Structure and organization of the federal and state criminal court systems and personnel.   FS: 4/5/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Criminal Law
description: Origin and development of criminal law in America. Basic elements of crimes and defenses.

subject: CRJU
name: Drugs and Crime
description: Overview of criminal justice system responses to illegal substances. Relationship between substance abuse and crime.

subject: CRJU
name: Violence in America
description: Historical overview of violence in American society, including theoretical perspectives on the causes and prevention of violence.

subject: CRJU
name: Sociology of Crime
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of criminals.   FS: 12/04/2019.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Juvenile Delinquency
description: Social factors in the development, identification, and treatment of delinquents.   FS: 06/12/2013.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Independent Study
description: Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and Office of Academic Programs is required for undergraduate students.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Analyzing Homicide
description: Relationships between patterns and trends in homicide, and theoretical explanations for why offenders engage in homicide.   FS: 04/06/2022.

subject: CRJU
name: Victimization
description: Causes and consequences of criminal victimization and public policy responses to victimization issues.

subject: CRJU
name: Alternatives to Incarceration
description: Correctional alternatives to imprisonment including probation, parole, and various community correctional programs.

subject: CRJU
name: Street Gangs: Structure, Activity, and Response
description: Course covers the theoretical and empirical work on gangs, gang members, and gang activity along with insight on these issues from a practitioner perspective. It then examines the variety of policy responses from government and community organizations.

subject: CRJU
name: Criminal Justice Intelligence
description: An investigation of the motivations to commit crime. The course presents profiles of the targets of crimes and provides strategic and tactical assessments of police investigations and intelligence.

subject: CRJU
name: Hate Crimes
description: An examination of the causes and responses to hate crimes. The course also provide a foundation for understanding crimes motivated by racial, gender, religious, disability, and sexual orientation biases.

subject: CRJU
name: Criminal Justice and Mental Health
description: Interface between the mental health sciences and the criminal justice system.   FS: 12/7/2016.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Communities and Crime
description: Relationship between criminality and community characteristics, with particular attention to how variation in community structure, organization, and culture impacts crime.

subject: CRJU
name: Homeland Security and Terrorism
description: The nature of terrorism; its history; its methodology; and its application to criminological theory.   FS: 12/6/2017.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Selected Topics in Criminal Justice Policy
description: Public policy responses to crime, its formation, and its impact on society. Individual topics to be announced by title. May be repeated with consent of advisor.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Special Topics
description: Topics in criminology and criminal justice. Individual topics to be announced by title. May be repeated once with consent of advisor.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Internship
description: A supervised experiential course in a criminal justice agency. Contract approved by instructor, advisor, and Office of Academic Programs is required for undergraduate students.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Critical Incident Management for Criminal Justice
description: Leadership and management strategies for criminal justice agencies during critical incidents and disasters including multi-agency and multi-jurisdictional response.

subject: CRJU
name: Information-Based Management in Criminal Justice
description: The collection and use of information and data-driven analysis in criminal justice organizations.

subject: CRJU
name: Inmates and Prisons
description: Examination of issues affecting prisons and the inmates confined within them. Specific topics of study will include the philosophy and goals of imprisonment, institutional crowding, inmate rights, inmate adaptation, and individual and collective misconduct.   CL: 2020.

subject: CRJU
name: Adolescent Mentoring
